long_desc.thetext:
I have been experimenting with using TreeViewerEditor and related facilities, such as FocusCellOwnerDrawHighlighter. Have noticed a few problems with the current implementation:
1. At least on Windows, the background color for the selection in the tree should alter depending on whether or not the overall tree widget has focus or not. FocusCellOwnerDrawHighlighter does not implement this feedback.
2. If you don't set SWT.FULL_SELECTION when creating the tree, the selection doesn't get painted on any column besides the first one. If this is expected behavior, this should at least be in javadoc.
3. Regardless of whether or not SWT.FULL_SELECTION is used, the selection extent in the first column is not restricted to the text (as it typical on Windows for trees). It goes all the way to the left margin of the tree widget and covers tree controls, icon and the checkbox. This doesn't look particularly good. Following native behavior here would be desirable.
The FocusCellOwnerDrawHighlighter also needs javadoc since it's public API.

(In reply to comment #0) > I have been experimenting with using TreeViewerEditor and related facilities, > such as FocusCellOwnerDrawHighlighter. Have noticed a few problems with the > current implementation: > > 1. At least on Windows, the background color for the selection in the tree > should alter depending on whether or not the overall tree widget has focus or > not. FocusCellOwnerDrawHighlighter does not implement this feedback. >
You mean that the selection color is gray when the Tree/Table looses the focus?
> 2. If you don't set SWT.FULL_SELECTION when creating the tree, the selection > doesn't get painted on any column besides the first one. If this is expected > behavior, this should at least be in javadoc.
Expected but JavaDoc must be added. When using Multi-TreeViewer/TableViewer in conjunction with CellEditor one always has to use SWT.FULL_SELECTION else the editor activation code is not guaranteed to work (SWT-limitation).
> > 3. Regardless of whether or not SWT.FULL_SELECTION is used, the selection > extent in the first column is not restricted to the text (as it typical on > Windows for trees). It goes all the way to the left margin of the tree widget > and covers tree controls, icon and the checkbox. This doesn't look particularly > good. Following native behavior here would be desirable.
We need to look up how the TreeEditor is doing the calculation and use the same algorithm.
> > The FocusCellOwnerDrawHighlighter also needs javadoc since it's public API. >
Accepted.
Do you have time to contribute a patch?

> You mean that the selection color is gray when the Tree/Table looses the > focus?
On my machine, the selection color when Tree has focus is medium gray, but when the tree looses focus the selection is light gray.
> Do you have time to contribute a patch?
I am willing to work on a patch, but I would need someone to point me in at least approx direction.

Created attachment 86709 Patch to make focus out color configurable / SWT-Tree first column padding
I gave it a try and it seems to be easier than I thought. I only tested on OS-X but here it works as expected. Could you apply the patch and run Snippet26 and report if this works on Win32.
I'd like to make the Tree-padding configurable before adding patch but this is trivial.

(In reply to comment #2) > > You mean that the selection color is gray when the Tree/Table looses the > > focus? > > On my machine, the selection color when Tree has focus is medium gray, but when > the tree looses focus the selection is light gray. > > > Do you have time to contribute a patch? > > I am willing to work on a patch, but I would need someone to point me in at > least approx direction. >
Thanks! The patch I attached can be used as a starting point (or maybe it is the solution already ;-)

Created attachment 86717 Screen shot showing effect of patch 1.
Wow, that was quick! Tried the patch on WinXP with Snippet26. The color now looks right when Tree has focus as well as when the tree doesn't have focus. Then I tried it with my code and noticed something odd. It looks like the tree outline lines are now gone. See attached screen shot. I will attach another screen shot showing what it looked like before the patch.

Created attachment 86719 Screen shot without the patch
Looks like the missing tree lines are not the result of this patch, but rather a separate issue completely. This screen shot shows what the UI looks like without the patch.

Created attachment 86720 Screen shot showing what the same UI looks like natively
This screen shot shows the same UI before I started making changes to use the TreeViewerEditor infrastructure. Note that in this case, the tree does not have SWT.FULL_SELECTION enabled, but I don't think that should effect the outline lines.

Noticed another problem. Let me know if I should be opening separate bugs instead. I will record it here for now so that I don't loose track of it.
If you have an active selection (doesn't matter which column) and check the checkbox that's in a row different from the row of the currently-selected cell, the visual representation of the selection is gone. The in-memory representation of the active cell appears to be still intact. If I use keyboard to navigate, the next cell that's selected is the one that I would expect based on the active cell prior to checking the checkbox.

(In reply to comment #6) > Created an attachment (id=86719) [details] > Screen shot without the patch > > Looks like the missing tree lines are not the result of this patch, but rather > a separate issue completely. This screen shot shows what the UI looks like > without the patch. >
Hm. Looks like an SWT Problem with owner-draw enabled.

(In reply to comment #8) > Noticed another problem. Let me know if I should be opening separate bugs > instead. I will record it here for now so that I don't loose track of it. > > If you have an active selection (doesn't matter which column) and check the > checkbox that's in a row different from the row of the currently-selected cell, > the visual representation of the selection is gone. The in-memory > representation of the active cell appears to be still intact. If I use keyboard > to navigate, the next cell that's selected is the one that I would expect based > on the active cell prior to checking the checkbox. >
Ok. It seems the checking doesn't fire an EraseItem event, will investigate and come back to you early next week.

Created attachment 86730 Fix for bug mentionned in comment 8
This was not easy to track down :-)
The focus manager listened to SWT.Selection and Check/Uncheck are also represented as Selection-Events with a detail-value of SWT.CHECK but this selection event should not update the focus cell.
Created attachment 86731 Patch for test snippet

Created attachment 86732 The not showing of dotted lines is an SWT-Problem
I'm not sure this is an SWT-bug or feature but you can force I'll file a bug and ask if this is intentional

Created attachment 86735 Final patch with JavaDoc updates, configurable padding support
waiting of SWT-Team to comment on the referenced bug but IMHO this is the final solution from JFace to address all issues mentionned in this bug

Created attachment 86743 Screen shot after patch #3
Got the latest patch and applied the workaround for the SWT issue to my code. It's looking much better. I can confirm that the checkbox issue has been resolved. The padding, however, isn't quite right. See the screen shot. The selection should not be covering the icon. The native behavior is to only cover text in the first column.
Thanks again for jumping on this and fixing all of these issues so quickly!

Created attachment 86760 Fixing remaining problems
Using the correct SWT-API now to fix the remaining problems. I need to test on Linux and OS-X before releasing.
When it comes the Dotted-Line problem. I'm not sure how to proceed because it seems it works as designed. In our case we can use OS.TVS_FULLROWSELECT and OS.TVS_HASLINES can be used together but because we are showing the selection using owner draw to highlight the cell it seems to work maybe we will get feedback from SWT-Team.
Boris I added new API in ViewerRow/TableViewerRow/TreeViewerRow and FocusCellOwnerDrawHighlighter could you review?
Finally I removed the work-around which was added because of a bug I can't reproduce currently.
Created attachment 86761 Fixed @since 3.4
The latest patch fixes the remaining issue described in Comment #15. Looks good. Thanks.
Boris please review the new API added.

What about Vista? On Vista, selected rows have a gradient, and they "glow". A single color is not enough to capture this. Are we OK with implementing something that will look non-native on some platforms?
I don't have a Vista install to try this on, but following native appearance and behavior as much as possible is very important. I will try to get a Vista image to try this out as soon as possible.

I'd like to fix this bug (the check selection problem) and open a new bug for VISTA L&F. I take the point here that this an implementation any implementor can create on its own (beside the fixes already in this patch) and replace our default one we provide here.
Let's try to get this into M5 so that Kosta can use it and give feedback before the API freeze (M6).
released to CVS-HEAD >= 20070201
Created attachment 88561 Check-Snippet
Tom or Boris could you verify this please?
Verified in I20080205 by running the test-snippet.
I've filed bug 218129 to discuss better Vista L&F integration

attachment.desc: Patch to make focus out color configurable / SWT-Tree first column padding
Screen shot showing effect of patch 1.
Screen shot showing what the same UI looks like natively
Fix for bug mentionned in comment 8
The not showing of dotted lines is an SWT-Problem
Final patch with JavaDoc updates, configurable padding support
